documentation.title: At what point is a marriage lawful?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: When my sister got married, at the rehearsal the celebrant said he had to be careful what he said and when because if he said 'too much' they would end up married sooner than they planned. Although this was a year or two ago a question has lingered: at what point in a ceremony, taking place in England and Wales, does the marriage become official?

I'm not concerned with wedding scenes for TV and film because there are precursor steps leading up to the ceremony that would prevent an 'accidental' marriage. I'm also like to know if there are any differences between marriage and civil partnerships.

All the results my searches have returned are related to what conditions make a marriage legal rather than the point it becomes legal.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The celebrant was (hopefully) joking. They (should) know that you can’t get married **accidentally**. Marriage requires genuine consent of both parties which participation in a **rehearsal** denies is there.

Technically, the parties are married when all the legal formalities are complete. Practically, they are married when they believe they are. 

Legally, they are married when the court considering the question in the case decides they are \- a court would only be doing this if there was some issue that hinged on it and it would look at all the evidence. For example, if there were doubt about intention then the court might decide they were never married. Alternatively, even if the technical requirements were not met, the court might decide that they are married and if necessary the date/time this occurred.

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In England and Wales, at what point does a marriage legally become official?

A) As soon as the celebrant begins speaking during the ceremony
B) When the couple exchanges rings
C) When all legal formalities are complete and the court recognizes it as valid
D) Immediately after the couple says "I do"

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, a marriage legally becomes official when all the legal formalities are complete and, if challenged, when a court recognizes it as valid. The answer emphasizes that there isn't a single, specific moment during the ceremony that instantly makes the marriage official.

Option A is incorrect because the celebrant's words alone do not constitute a legal marriage, especially during a rehearsal.

Option B is incorrect because exchanging rings is a symbolic gesture and not a legal requirement for marriage.

Option D is incorrect because saying "I do" is part of the ceremony but doesn't automatically finalize the marriage legally.

The question tests understanding of the legal complexities surrounding marriage formalization and the role of courts in determining marital status if disputed.

documentation.title: How long can a musical quote be and what counts as such?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Recently I've found out that copyright owners are claiming profits of YouTube videos where allegedly their content is used. Specifically, [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYmzVHRAo94) was [claimed to be a copyright infringement](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uHh8nPj5SDY). 

I'm aware of other questions related to copyright and YouTube policies, however my question is very specific. In the claimed video YouTuber plays on acoustic guitar for 25 seconds without even singing what for me looks like a quotation.

Is there anything in US copyright law regulating how long and in which exact form (exact record or performance etc.) a musical quote can be, if such concept is a thing at all? While this video is on a commercial channel it's quite evident that guy did it for educational purposes. 

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/UtLG5.jpg)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: *"But he doesn't even sing!"*

If music only consisted of lyrics, you'd have a point. But you already said exactly how the infringement happened: playing the guitar.

The content usage is clear: the video uses the song's melody, and therefore is infringing on copyright.

It doesn't matter how long or little is played. Copyright infringement suits have been successful when only seconds of the original work were copied, because that short section is important enough to require protection, and its use to deserve compensation (in the extreme, because it comprises the entire work).

> While this video is on a commercial channel it's quite evident that guy did it for educational purposes.

If done for commercial purposes, this is almost surely the deciding factor over others in USA fair use, and clearly disallows UK fair dealing, and in most other jurisdictions would tend to make it disallowed usage as well.

Put more simply, you can't justify infringing copyright in the material used for teaching when you're getting paid for that teaching, any more than you can justify theft of real or tangible property on the same basis.

1.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided copyright information:

Question: A YouTuber creates an educational video on their monetized channel where they play 25 seconds of a copyrighted song on acoustic guitar without singing. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding copyright law in this situation?

A) The use is likely fair use because it's for educational purposes and only 25 seconds long.
B) The use is permissible because the YouTuber didn't sing the lyrics, only played the melody.
C) The copyright owner has no valid claim because the performance is on a different instrument than the original.
D) The use likely infringes copyright, despite being short and for educational purposes, because it's on a commercial channel.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D because even though the use is short (25 seconds) and for educational purposes, it's still likely to be considered copyright infringement. The key factors are:

1. The video uses the song's melody, which is protected by copyright.
2. The length of use doesn't matter - even short clips can infringe if they're important enough.
3. While educational use can sometimes be fair use, the fact that this is on a commercial (monetized) YouTube channel weighs heavily against fair use.
4. Not singing the lyrics doesn't matter - the melody alone is copyrightable.
5. Performing on a different instrument doesn't avoid infringement - it's still recognizably the same musical work.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect because they misunderstand key aspects of copyright law as it applies to this situation.

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A software developer wants to create and sell a mobile application that utilizes data from alltransistors.com. According to the website's terms and conditions, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this proposed use of the site's content?

A) The developer can freely use the content for commercial purposes as long as they acknowledge the source.

B) The developer needs to obtain explicit permission from alltransistors.com before using the content commercially.

C) The developer can use the content commercially if they haven't received a response to their permission request emails.

D) The developer is prohibited from using the content for commercial purposes based on the terms and conditions.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
The terms and conditions of alltransistors.com clearly state that "The content of the pages of this website is for your general information and use only." This limits the use to personal, non-commercial purposes. Furthermore, the terms specify that "Your use of any information or materials on this website is entirely at your own risk, for which we shall not be liable." This indicates that the site does not grant permission for commercial use or redistribution of its content.

Option A is incorrect because the terms do not allow free commercial use with acknowledgment. 
Option B is misleading because while seeking permission is a good practice, the terms already prohibit such use without mentioning exceptions through permission.
Option C is incorrect because lack of response to permission requests does not imply consent, especially when the terms explicitly limit use.
Option D is correct because it aligns with the restrictive nature of the terms regarding commercial use of the site's content.

documentation.title: Blockchain based insurance policy brokerage - requirements and restrictions
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have some questions regarding the concept and legality of a blockchain based peer\-to\-peer insurance platform.

**A little background:**
The basic idea is for people being given the possibility to "insure" another users private property, whatever that may be in any specific case. The insurer would then have the opportunity
to claim profits on a timely schedule, while the insured could claim the collateral provided by the insurer, if the requirements both parties agreed upon were to be met.
The insurance contracts themselves would be initialized, maintained and eventually resolved through a series of transparent open sourced smart contracts. Smart contracts are essentially little programs, that run on the blockchain. The can
be reviewed by anyone interested.

**Questions:**

1. Is it legally necessary to formally record such a relation between two (or more) private persons? With the crypto space currently being so very unregulated, are there even laws applicable to this matter?
2. How difficult would it be for users of such a service to declare the income generated through anything related to the platform? Would this be regarded
as a form of self\-employment, would they have to register a company or any of the likes?
3. Would the platform itself, being the service provider, have to be registered in any way? The main aim of the platform would of course be income generation.

**Legal accountability:**

1. Would we need to explicitly declare a disclaimer to prevent being sued if a user considers the rejection of their claim unjust?
Since this is a peer\-to\-peer system, the platform itself will mostly be uninvolved in the decision process. Instead this will be the duty of an independant third party comprised of individual users.
2. Could the platform be held accountable in case of lost user funds? Only if the platform were at fault? (as in, did the platform's source code cause the issue?)
3. Can a strictly blockchain based platform even be sued? Only if it is legally registered?
4. Is there an exact legal counterpart as to the role the platform would assume in this system? It provides the framework upon wich the insurance policies are designed, contracts are established
and payouts are issued. It does not directly take part in insurance business.

Feel free to let me know, if any further clarification is needed.

**Edit:**
Since jurisdictional specification was suggested, let's assume it to be Switzerland and the U.S.A.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 1. Although crypto space may be little regulated, insurance is in most jurisdictions highly regulated. Any such arrangement would need to comply with current laws on insurance, until and unless modified laws to cover this sort of thing are passed, and then it would need to comply with those.
2. Tax authorities generally allow one to declare "other business income" or "other investment income" without forming a legal entity. I cannot say how such income would be classified in any given jurisdiction.
3. Whether the platform, or some legal entity associated with the platform, would need to be registered will depend on the current laws and regulations governing insurance, and on the way in which teh contracts are structured.
4. A disclaimer cannot prevent one from being sued. The contracts would need to carefully and explicitly state who is liable for what.
5. Programs cannot be held accountable for anything. Legal entities, including operators of programs, can be. If negligence in the creation or operation of a program causes a loss, the operator may well be liable.
6. Programs cannot be sued for anything. Legal entities, including operators of programs, can be. It may well be essential to constitute the "platform" as a legal entity of some sort. Otherwise its operator will be liable for its actions.
7. I cannot be sure. I once encountered a somewhat similar system in which insurance was provided by individuals exchanging contracts, so that in a sense each member insured all the others. There was a company that supervised and provided legal and administrative services to the group of individuals, and collected fees for this. That sounds a bit similar to the suggested platform, but I don't know exactly how that company was organized. The system was called "NJ CURE". I don't know if it is still in operation.

3.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: A blockchain-based peer-to-peer insurance platform is being developed. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal and regulatory implications of such a platform?

A) The platform can operate without any legal registration or compliance with insurance regulations due to the unregulated nature of the crypto space.

B) Users of the platform would need to register as insurance companies to participate in providing insurance services.

C) The platform would likely need to comply with existing insurance regulations and may need to be registered as a legal entity, even if it only provides the framework for peer-to-peer insurance contracts.

D) A disclaimer would be sufficient to protect the platform from any legal liability related to insurance claims or lost user funds.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: While the crypto space is relatively unregulated, insurance is highly regulated in most jurisdictions. The platform would likely need to comply with existing insurance laws and regulations, even if it only provides the framework for peer-to-peer insurance contracts. It may need to be registered as a legal entity to operate legally and manage potential liabilities. A disclaimer alone would not be sufficient to prevent lawsuits or absolve the platform of all responsibilities. Users probably wouldn't need to register as insurance companies, but they may need to declare income from the platform. The unregulated nature of crypto does not exempt the platform from complying with insurance regulations.

documentation.title: Can the Developer of a Program be penalized if it is used illegally?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If a developer writes a program, for example a password cracker or a code decipher, and it is used illegally, will the developer or the user get punished? A password cracker could be used, for example, if you forgot your email password, and that is perfectly legal. But you could also use the password cracker to hack into someone else's account. Same deal for a code decipher (it could be used legally or illegally.) So my question is: if a user uses a program illegally, is the user or the developer punished? Is there something a developer can do (like put a user agreement that states you should not use it illegally?)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The simple answer is yes. There's a famous case that illustrates this: A\&M Records, Inc. v. Napster, Inc., 239 F.3d 1004 (2001\).

A number of record companies successfully sued *Napster* for infringing their various intellectual property rights.

Essentially, the finding came down to the fact that:

* Napster's program (of the same name) allows for the exchange of copyrighted material, ***and*** *Napster* had actual knowledge that specific infringing material was available using its system, and that it did not remote the material (by blocking access to the system or otherwise).
* Napster did not police the index of files that they maintained, and so were liable for vicarious infringement.

The longer answer to your question is *it depends*. Based on the Napster precedent, it seems it would depend (at least) on whether: 

* the program may have legitimate uses
* you are aware that it can be used for illegal purpose
* you have a means of monitoring the activity
* you have a means of restricting use of the program
* you financially benefit from the activities of the users

Many developers will include some warning about using the software only for legal purposes. I don't think such a warning has ever been tested, and even if it were, it's unlikely to make a difference if the clear purpose of the software is to perform illegal acts.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A software developer creates a program that can be used to decrypt encrypted messages. The program has legitimate uses, such as recovering lost personal data, but can also be used for illegal purposes like intercepting private communications. Under what circumstances is the developer most likely to be held legally responsible for illegal use of their software by users?

A) If the developer includes a user agreement stating the software should not be used illegally
B) If the software has any potential illegal uses, regardless of legitimate purposes
C) If the developer is aware of specific illegal use, has the ability to prevent it, and benefits financially from it
D) If the software is open-source and freely available online

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Based on the precedent set by the Napster case, a developer is most likely to be held legally responsible if they are aware of specific illegal use of their software, have the means to prevent or restrict such use, and financially benefit from the activities of the users. Simply including a user agreement (A) is unlikely to provide sufficient protection if other factors indicate the developer's knowledge and complicity. The mere possibility of illegal use (B) is not enough if the software also has legitimate purposes. Making software open-source and free (D) does not inherently protect the developer from liability if they are actively involved in its illegal use.

documentation.title: GDPR Compliance - Password Protected Documents in AutoRecovery
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I'm working with personnel data in my job, including lots of details which I know to be sensitive and most certainly covered by GDPR.

In order to maintain compliance with the regulations while preserving the ability of our team to work on the same spreadsheets, we have hidden sheets and locked the Excel workbook every time it has been saved. This effectively obscures all personal data behind password protection.

A problem I have noticed however is that **once the spreadsheet is unlocked and in use, MS Excel makes "AutoRecovery" copies** of it which are accessible upon opening Excel.

I wanted to check where things stand under these circumstances \- of Excel autosaves effectively leaving a copy of the document without password protection. I presume this is non\-compliant, if this is the case, is the only way around this to turn off autosaving and recovery mechanisms from Excel (providing this is possible)?

Many thanks for any answers to what I hope is a fairly clear\-cut question, but I can't be sure of my assumptions on the matter.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: What does your [Data Protection Officer](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_protection_officer) say?
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It’s their role to be aware of and assess if you policies, procedures and processes comply with the [principles](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-5-gdpr/). For the particular application is it:

* “specified, explicit and legitimate purposes”?
* “adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary”
* “kept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processed”
* “processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security of the personal data, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measures”

And can you clearly demonstrate compliance with the above?

Just a personal observation: WTF are you using a spreadsheet for what is clearly a database problem? This is several dozen steps away from best practice data security.

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company is handling sensitive personnel data covered by GDPR using Excel spreadsheets. They implement password protection and hidden sheets to secure the data. However, they discover that Excel's AutoRecovery feature creates unprotected copies of the workbook. Which of the following actions would be most appropriate to address this issue and ensure GDPR compliance?

A) Continue using the current method, as password protection is sufficient for GDPR compliance
B) Consult with the company's Data Protection Officer to assess the situation and develop a compliant solution
C) Immediately switch to using a dedicated database system instead of spreadsheets
D) Turn off Excel's AutoRecovery feature without further consultation

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A) is incorrect because the current method leaves unprotected copies via AutoRecovery, which is likely non-compliant with GDPR.
B) is correct because the Data Protection Officer is responsible for ensuring GDPR compliance and can provide guidance on appropriate measures.
C) While using a database might be a good long-term solution, immediately switching without proper planning could introduce new risks.
D) While turning off AutoRecovery might solve the immediate issue, it doesn't address the broader compliance concerns and should not be done without proper assessment.

Consulting the Data Protection Officer allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the current practices, assessment of risks, and development of a compliant solution that adheres to GDPR principles of data protection and security.

documentation.title: Could jury instructions reasonably be viewed as a kind of expert witness testimony?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: It seems to me that jury instructions could be viewed as a kind of testimony provided by an expert witness (the judge) about what verdict must be returned based on what facts the jury finds to be true. Like witnesses, judges are human and subject to biases and external pressures, and it seems like it would be reasonable to assume that their jury instructions could reflect that.

Viewing jury instructions this way I think would mean that it is part of the role of the jury to determine which parts of the jury instructions should be considered fact, and I think it would also mean that jury nullification wouldn't necessarily mean that a jury [returns "a verdict of 'Not Guilty' despite its belief that the defendant is guilty of the violation charged"](https://law.stackexchange.com/a/112); it could just mean that the jury doesn't accept all of the statements in the jury instructions, such as the judge's interpretation of the law, as fact.

Could jury instructions reasonably be viewed as a kind of expert witness testimony? If not, what are the main problems with viewing them this way?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: No. There is a clear distinction between:

* evidence (or testimony), which consists of statements of fact given by witnesses on oath (subject to prosecution for perjury), governed by the rules of evidence, and which the jury is required to consider but not accept (in the sense that a verdict which is not supported by the evidence can be set aside on appeal),
* submissions, which consist of argument by the lawyers for the parties, which the jury is not required to consider or accept, and
* directions, which consist of statements of law given by the judge, which the jury is required to accept.

The jury is required by its oath to follow the law as stated by the judge, even if it is wrong. The remedy for erroneous trial directions (an appeal) is different to the remedy for erroneous evidence (a perjury prosecution in the case of deliberate lies; nothing in the case of innocent errors).

Because the jury has the power, but not the right, to nullify a charge by disobeying the judge’s directions, there is a sense in which the jury is free to reject the judge’s directions just as it is free to reject evidence. However, this is completely inconsistent with the theory that defines the roles of judge and jury. There is no *legal* basis for viewing judicial directions as a kind of expert testimony.

‘The power, but not the right’
------------------------------

Obie 2\.0 asked about this phrase. It coems from the [Case of the Dean of St Asaph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_of_the_Dean_of_St_Asaph), which is reported at *R v Shipley* (1784\) [4 Doug 73](https://books.google.com.au/books?id=hSdFAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA73). The relevant passage is summarised in Lord Devlin's *[Trial by Jury](https://socialsciences.exeter.ac.uk/media/universityofexeter/schoolofhumanitiesandsocialsciences/law/pdfs/Trial_by_Jury.pdf)* (1956\), at p 87:

> **Jury’s Power of Acquittal**
> 
> 
> There may well be cases in which the killing is not in doubt and the formal direction not to return a verdict of manslaughter is therefore tantamount to a direction to return a verdict of Guilty. Still, if the direction is ignored, the court must, I think, accept the verdict. There is no way in which a verdict of acquittal can be nullified. As Lord Chief Justice Mansfield put it in 1784: “It is the duty of the judge, in all cases of general justice, to tell the jury how to do right, though they have it in *their power* to do wrong, which is a matter entirely between God and their own consciences.” Mr. Justice Willes said: “I admit the jury have the *power* of finding a verdict against the law and so they have of finding a verdict against evidence, but I deny they have the *right* to do so.”

The Chief Justice of Australia held to similar effect in *Gammage v The Queen* (1969\) [122 CLR 444](http://www.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/viewdoc/au/cases/cth/HCA/1969/68.html?context=1;query=gammage;mask_path=), writing:

> \[The jury] have no right, in my opinion, to return a verdict of manslaughter where they are satisfied of murder. But, as I have said, persistence by them in returning another verdict must ultimately result in the acceptance of that verdict. In that sense, but in no other sense, it is both within their power and, if you will, their privilege to return a wrong verdict.

To answer Obie 2\.0's question, the jury has the *power* to ignore the judge's directions, because – at least at the time Lord Devlin was writing in 1956 – a verdict of acquittal could not be nullified. However, the jury does not have the *right* to do so because the law requires it to follow the directions.

As Ed999 observes, the law governing jury trials does vary between jurisdictions. In particular, some jurisdictions (which lack the United States' constitutional [double jeopardy clause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_Jeopardy_Clause)) now allow for a jury acquittal to be set aside on appeal. However, the fundamental distinction between a witness’s evidence and a judge’s directions was established in England centuries ago, and remains applicable throughout the common law world.

It is worth specifically mentioning the United States because [jury nullification remains a controversial topic in that jurisdiction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jury_nullification_in_the_United_States). However, the basic principle that the jury is legally required to follow the judge’s directions was established in *[Sparf v. United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparf_v._United_States)*, [156 U.S. 51](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/156/51/case.html) (1895\), and described by Ginsburg J (albeit in a dissenting judgment) as ‘conclusive’ in *[Honda Motor Co. v. Oberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honda_Motor_Co._v._Oberg)*, [512 U.S. 415](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/512/415/case.html), 447 (1994\). In *Sparf*, the opinion of the court was:

> We must hold firmly to the doctrine that in the courts of the United States it is the duty of juries in criminal cases to take the law from the court and apply that law to the facts as they find them to be from the evidence.

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between jury instructions and expert witness testimony in a trial?

A) Jury instructions are a form of expert witness testimony provided by the judge.

B) Jury instructions and expert witness testimony are both optional for the jury to consider.

C) Jury instructions are binding directives on law that the jury must follow, while expert witness testimony is evidence the jury may evaluate.

D) Jury instructions and expert witness testimony are both subject to perjury laws if found to be false.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The key distinction is that jury instructions are directions on the law given by the judge, which the jury is legally required to follow. Expert witness testimony, on the other hand, is evidence presented by witnesses that the jury may evaluate but is not obligated to accept. While juries have the power to disregard instructions through nullification, they do not have the legal right to do so. Expert testimony is subject to rules of evidence, while jury instructions are statements of law. This fundamental difference in their nature and how juries are expected to treat them makes C the correct answer.

documentation.title: Do you get to keep a fraudulent money transfer that you are entitled to?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Reading this story got me speculating: [https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021\-02\-17/citi\-can\-t\-have\-its\-900\-million\-back](https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-02-17/citi-can-t-have-its-900-million-back)
TLDR: CitiBank accidentally wired $900m to creditors of a company they were the administrative agent for. The company had wanted to restructure the debt and avoid paying the full amount, but some poor shmuck at Citi made a whoopsie. Citi sued for the money and lost, because of the “discharge\-for\-value defense”:

> The recipient is allowed to keep the funds if they discharge a valid debt, the recipient made no misrepresentations to induce the payment, and the recipient did not have notice of the mistake

What if the transfer had been fraudulently made by a hacker who had paid off several creditors to make it impossible to pinpoint what creditor he was working for and most recipients genuinely didn't know they were going to get the money they were entitled to, but otherwise 100% criminal. Would the doctrine still apply?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The linked Bloomberg story quotes the rule as:

> The recipient is allowed to keep the funds if they \[the funds] discharge a valid debt, the recipient made no misrepresentations to induce the payment, and the recipient did not have notice of the mistake.

If the recipient, or somone acting on behalf of the recipient, hacked the sender to induce the payment, that sounds like a form of misrepresentation to me. If the hacker is unconnected with the recipient there seems no way that the hacker benefits financially, although I suppose a hacker might simply want to cause an amusing disruption.

As I understand it this rule only applies when the sender in fact owes a debt to the recipient that the transfer pays off.

If the hacker were working for one of a large group of recipients, most of whom are innocent, and subsequent analysis establishes that there was a hacker, but not who the hacker was or which of the many recipients the hacker was working for, I suspect, but cannot prove, that the doctrine would not apply, because the transfer was not a valid but incorrect act by the sender, but was a fraudulent intervention in the sender's procedures.

7.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A hacker fraudulently transfers $500 million from BigBank to pay off the debts of 100 different companies that BigBank legitimately owes money to. 99 of these companies had no knowledge of or involvement in the hack. The hack is discovered, but investigators cannot determine which company the hacker was working for. BigBank sues to recover the funds. Under these circumstances, how would the "discharge-for-value" defense likely apply?

A) The defense would apply to all 100 companies, allowing them to keep the funds.
B) The defense would not apply to any of the companies, and all would have to return the funds.
C) The defense would apply to the 99 companies not involved in the hack, but not to the company that employed the hacker.
D) The court would likely rule that the defense does not apply due to the fraudulent nature of the transfer, even though most recipients are innocent.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: While the "discharge-for-value" defense typically allows recipients to keep funds if they discharge a valid debt, the recipient made no misrepresentations, and had no notice of a mistake, this situation is complicated by the fraudulent nature of the transfer. Even though 99 of the companies are innocent and the funds did discharge valid debts, the fact that the transfer was initiated by a criminal act (hacking) rather than a mistake by the sender would likely lead a court to rule that the doctrine does not apply. The fraudulent intervention in the sender's procedures undermines the basis of the defense, which assumes an error by the sender, not an external criminal act. Additionally, the inability to identify the specific company involved in the fraud could lead to a blanket ruling against applying the defense to protect the integrity of the financial system and discourage future similar schemes.

documentation.title: Costa charging different prices for same item
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Last week I stopped at services and ordered in Costa two coffees. One Caramel Cappuccino (£3\.89\) and one Speciality Vanilla (£3\.99\). When I got to pay and bill was £8\.18 I figured something must have gone wrong since it should not exceed £8\. It turns out they have charged me Cappuccino (£3\.59\) \+ Caramel (£0\.50\) and another Cappuccino (£3\.59\) \+ Vanilla (£0\.50\) that totalled up to £8\.18\. 
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/bh21L.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/bh21L.png)

I then asked is there a difference in preparation of drinks (Caramel Cappuccino vs Cappuccino \+ Caramel and Speciality Vanilla vs Cappuccino \+ Vanilla), and there was no difference, they are exactly same drink that are being charged differently depending on how cashier feels like. 

**Are they allowed by law to charge different prices for same things?**

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In common law contract law, the price tag or posted price is only an invitation to treat. The offer and acceptance of the offer happen at the cash register. You are free to back out of the deal when you become aware of the higher price at the register.

Barring a consumer protection law that forces vendors to honour listed prices, common law contract law applies.

It is hard to prove a negative and I have limited exposure to UK law, but these two articles lead me to believe that the UK doesn't have a law requiring vendors to honour posted prices:

* [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/money\-saving\-tips/10602641/Price\-glitches\-Do\-retailers\-have\-to\-honour\-pricing\-mistakes.html](http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/money-saving-tips/10602641/Price-glitches-Do-retailers-have-to-honour-pricing-mistakes.html)

> If an item is priced incorrectly on the shelf, or scans at the wrong price at the till, retailers are under no obligation to honour it, under the Sale of Goods Act.

* [http://www.theguardian.com/money/2012/sep/10/does\-shop\-honour\-price\-shelf](http://www.theguardian.com/money/2012/sep/10/does-shop-honour-price-shelf)

> price tag is not a contract. It is an "invitation to treat" ie it is inviting the customer to make an offer to purchase and the retailer doesn't have to accept that offer. A contract is only formed when the shop accepts a payment

8.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Based on UK contract law, what is the legal status of a price tag on an item in a store?

A) It represents a binding contract between the store and the customer.
B) It is considered an invitation to treat, not a firm offer.
C) It must be honored by law if a customer attempts to purchase at that price.
D) It is regulated by the Sale of Goods Act to prevent pricing mistakes.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) Incorrect. In UK contract law, a price tag does not constitute a binding contract between the store and the customer.

B) Correct. According to common law contract principles in the UK, a price tag is considered an "invitation to treat," which means it invites customers to make an offer to purchase, rather than being a firm offer itself.

C) Incorrect. UK law does not require vendors to honor posted prices. The contract is only formed when the shop accepts payment, typically at the cash register.

D) Incorrect. While the Sale of Goods Act is relevant to retail transactions, it does not specifically regulate price tags or require retailers to honor pricing mistakes.

This question tests understanding of basic contract law principles in retail settings, particularly the concept of "invitation to treat" and when a contract is actually formed in a retail transaction.

documentation.title: Legal age of adulthood
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If current law establishes that a fetus is considered life at it's first confirmed heartbeat, shouldn't life start then? At which point does one's age begin. Example: "a delivered baby" on 5/1/0000 would actually be older based on "first heartbeat" detected and not the delivery date? Is age even a question of law?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Age is computed based on date of birth. Age is a question of law, for laws regarding drinking, smoking, sex, voting, contractual responsibility, holding the office of president, and many other things.

9.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: According to current legal standards, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the determination of a person's age for legal purposes?

A) Age is calculated from the moment of conception, as this is when unique human DNA is formed.

B) Age begins at the detection of the first fetal heartbeat, as this is considered the start of life in some legal contexts.

C) Age is legally computed based on the date of birth, regardless of fetal development milestones.

D) Age determination varies depending on the specific legal context (e.g., voting rights vs. medical decisions).

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, age is legally computed based on the date of birth, not on any prenatal developmental stages. This is crucial for various legal matters such as determining eligibility for drinking, smoking, voting, contractual responsibilities, and even qualifying for the office of president. While there may be debates about when life begins from ethical or medical perspectives, the legal standard for age calculation remains tied to the date of birth. Options A and B, while reflecting arguments in ethical debates about the beginning of life, do not align with current legal standards for age computation. Option D, while it may seem plausible given the complexity of legal matters, is incorrect because age determination is consistently based on birth date across various legal contexts.

documentation.title: LLC liability for prior (sole proprietorship) product
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Say that I start selling a digital product while operating as a sole proprietorship. I later go through the process to form an LLC, and then continue to sell the product under the name of my LLC.

Does the LLC now assume all liability for past and future sales of the product? For example, say that John purchased my product while I was still selling as a sole proprietorship, but decides to sue me sometime after I form the LLC. Would I be personally liable, or would the LLC be liable?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Under most circumstance, you would continue to be liable for pre\-LLC obligations. You can't escape existing liability by changing the form of your business.

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: John began selling a digital product as a sole proprietor in January 2023. In June 2023, he formed an LLC and continued selling the same product under the LLC's name. In September 2023, a customer who purchased the product in March 2023 files a lawsuit related to the product. Who would be liable in this situation?

A) Only John personally, as the sale occurred before the LLC was formed
B) Only the LLC, as it now represents the business
C) Both John personally and the LLC would share liability equally
D) The LLC would be primarily liable, with John as a secondary defendant

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: The correct answer is A. John would be personally liable for the lawsuit because the sale occurred in March 2023, when he was operating as a sole proprietor. The formation of an LLC in June 2023 does not retroactively protect John from liabilities incurred before the LLC's creation. You cannot escape existing liability by changing the form of your business. The LLC would only be liable for sales and actions that occurred after its formation in June 2023.

Option B is incorrect because the LLC was not in existence at the time of the sale and cannot assume liability for actions before its creation.

Option C is incorrect because there is no equal sharing of liability between John and the LLC for pre-LLC actions.

Option D is incorrect because the LLC would not be liable at all for this particular sale, as it occurred before the LLC's formation.

documentation.title: Is Medium at risk of legal action?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Medium is sort of a content facilitator that charges its users for premium content and passes on part of that fee to authors, when the reader interacts with their work. However, over recent months, Medium has become increasingly focused on their own partnerships and internal publications, to the point where it's hard to argue that there is not an ethical conflict of interest. My question is whether there's a legal conflict of interest.

---

**General Idea**

To put it into general terms, consider three parties, A, B, and C. Party A offers party B and C the opportunity to profit from an operation, where parties B and C are in competition with one another for a finite amount of revenue in a given month (the total available from subscription fees in this case). Further suppose that the operation relies on party C for success (it seems easy to argue that Medium would have trouble surviving if only their own content was on the platform), and that party A provides biased support to party B. Finally, B and C are paid by A, from the revenue generated by the operation, rather than B and C obtaining the revenue directly from the operation's customers.

In such a scenario, there seems to be both an ethical issue and potentially legal issue. However, I am not familiar with any specific civil statutes that may come into play. Does it appear that the above scenario might violate any specific statute? The one potential reason why Medium might be saved from a valid lawsuit is that an author does not have to pay for the service. However, they are providing support, in their aggregate, through the massive volume of writing that they provide to the platform, without very much chance of being able to actually generate revenue. Precedent from cases involving pyramid schemes may apply here.

---

Michael Seifert raised an interesting question: "How would this be different from Publishing House A promoting a more profitable Author B instead of a less profitable Author C?"

The difference is that the publishing house does not rely on C's work for sales. To continue this analogy, consider a situation where the publishing house put in a request for chapters for an anthology, where the majority of the chapters came from C, and a few came from B. Further suppose that the publishing house paid its authors based on how many sales the respective authors generated, but almost exclusively promoted author B's website that sold the anthology. Even though readers likely would not purchase the anthology, without the chapters provided by C, because of A's disproportionate support of B, C would receive very little of the revenue stream.

---

BlueDogRanch made a point that Medium's terms of services "says nothing about being fair, or ethical." Agreed. Its terms of services say nothing, and therefore it does not say that they reserve the right to unfair, unequal, or unethical, biases. If the terms of service stated that Medium reserves the right to unequal promotion of work regardless of whether it reduces the potential revenue by other authors, then Medium would have a greater chance of winning in court, and greater justification for their actions. However, without such statements, it becomes less certain that one should assume that a content facilitator that provides revenue streams as part of a ***partner program*** would engage in actions that disproportionately shift revenue streams towards their own content. 

---

A final point. It seems that in California, an individual must pass the "ABC" test, at least when it comes to wage orders. Specifically, Medium's authors do not pass B: *the worker performs work that is outside the usual course of the hiring entity’s business*. It seems that, contrary to the suggestion that Medium's authors are subcontractors, they are, at least as far as California law is concerned, employees.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> *Is Medium at risk of legal action?*

They are, in as much as anyone or any company is due to the nature of civil law, i.e. just about anyone can take anyone else to civil court. That is where "legal conflicts of interest" are worked out. But I'd assume that Medium's lawyers have covered the bases in terms of adhering to state and federal laws that govern their business, their business model of paying authors and changing their business model; and ensure that they have a strong terms of service document for the site, and that document is legally binding for Medium's users.

Now, a disgruntled author could file against Medium, alleging fraud, uncompetitive practices, unfairness, conflicts of interest or anything else and attempt to recover damages for what they allege is a skewed payoff to authors or Medium's self\-serving policies. That said, authors and Medium are bound by the [Medium Terms of Service](https://medium.com/policy/medium-terms-of-service-9db0094a1e0f). The TOS says nothing about being fair, or ethical, and it clearly states that 

> By using Medium, you agree to these Terms. If you don’t agree to any
>  of the Terms, you can’t use Medium. We can change these Terms at any
>  time... If you don’t agree to them, you should delete your account
>  before they take effect, otherwise your use of the site and content
>  will be subject to the new Terms.

and

> Limitation of Liability. Medium won’t be liable to you for any damages
>  that arise from your using the Services.... This includes all types of
>  damages (indirect, incidental, consequential, special or exemplary).
>  And it includes all kinds of legal claims, such as breach of contract,
>  breach of warranty, tort, or any other loss.

That's the contract that the author would have to fight in court, and they will lose. They agreed to the terms of using Medium. Their only option, within reason other than a lawsuit, is to quit using Medium. An author could still file a lawsuit, but how far are they going to get? How much money do they have to spend to go up against Medium?

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Based on the legal analysis provided, which of the following statements most accurately reflects the potential legal situation for Medium regarding conflicts of interest with its authors?

A) Medium is completely protected from any legal action due to its Terms of Service agreement.

B) Authors have a strong case against Medium for unfair business practices and are likely to win in court.

C) Medium faces some legal risk, but its Terms of Service provide significant protection against most potential claims by authors.

D) California's ABC test definitively classifies Medium's authors as employees, exposing the company to immediate legal liability.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most accurate representation of Medium's legal situation. While Medium does face some legal risk, as any company does in civil law, its Terms of Service provide significant protection against most potential claims by authors. The Terms of Service explicitly limit Medium's liability and require users to agree to these terms to use the platform. This doesn't completely eliminate the possibility of legal action (ruling out option A), but it does make it difficult for authors to successfully sue Medium (ruling out option B). 

Option D is incorrect because, while the ABC test in California might suggest authors could be classified as employees, this hasn't been definitively established in court for Medium's specific case, and it doesn't necessarily expose the company to immediate legal liability.

Option C acknowledges both the potential for legal risk and the strong protections Medium has in place, making it the most balanced and accurate assessment of the situation described in the passage.

documentation.title: Obtaining copyright on a joint work produced by minors?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: How would you go about obtaining the copyright of work that is produced by minors? In terms of context, I am the head of a high school club that produces original animated content. The club provides members with the materials necessary to make said content. Is there a way of bringing the members into an agreement which gives their copyright protection of club related content to the club board? This ideally includes any of the intermediary content such as models and storyboards. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As the organizer/administrator of a world\-wide music production collaboration site, I've encountered something just like this. The answer we came up with was based on a "least resistance" kind of analysis, which found that trying to obtain and administer co\-copyright between a content creation\-enabling venue and the content creators themselves, was an absolute nightmare, in our case particularly because jurisdiction was so broad and diversified.

The answer for us was thus: "our content\-creation\-enabling venue makes no claims nor assertions with respect to original copyright of content produced by our members. All copyrights and other rights in any and all working materials and finished products remain vested in the authors themselves. Content creators/authors agree, by use of the venue, that they grant the venue a non\-exclusive license to use the working materials and finished products developed within the site for any purpose, including but not limited to display, education, creation of derivative works, promotion, or other uses that relate to the ongoing mandate and mission of the venue."

The key here is that you don't really want to own the copyright...you just want to protect your ability to use the content on an ongoing basis. Besides, demanding that a minor sign over copyright in creative works is a demon\-in\-wait, only looking for a chance to become litigation.

12.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A high school club produces original animated content with materials provided by the club. The club leader wants to secure rights to use the content created by the student members. Which of the following approaches is most appropriate and legally sound?

A) Have all club members sign over their copyrights to the club board, regardless of their age.

B) Implement a policy stating that all content created using club resources automatically becomes the property of the club.

C) Create an agreement where club members retain their copyrights but grant the club a non-exclusive license to use the content for club-related purposes.

D) Declare that since the club provides the materials, it inherently owns all content produced by members.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most appropriate and legally sound approach. This solution allows the student creators to retain their copyrights while granting the club the necessary rights to use the content. It avoids potential legal issues associated with minors signing over copyrights (A) or blanket claims of ownership (B and D). This approach also aligns with the "least resistance" method described in the documentation, which emphasizes protecting the ability to use the content rather than owning the copyright outright. It respects the rights of the creators while still allowing the club to utilize the content for its purposes, creating a balanced and legally safer arrangement.

documentation.title: Does double jeopardy protect a suspect from the consequences of admitting guilt after being declared not guilty?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I heard an anecdote of a suspect having just been declared "not guilty" due to insufficient evidence, then he said *"thanks, I won't do it again"*. It was used as an example of how dumb some people can be, and how the criminal just got what he deserved... however, can such a thing really happen? Wouldn't the suspect be protected by double jeopardy? (the story is set in a jurisdiction where double jeopardy exists)

Is the trial officially over as soon as the judge utters the final decision?

Consider the following cases:

1. The suspect carelessly and accidentally admits the crime in the courtroom right after being cleared, like in the example above ("thanks, I won't do it again") Can the decision be altered ten seconds after it's been made? If so, is such a careless utterance enough evidence to do so?
2. The suspect, having heard about double jeopardy, grins and says openly and voluntarily, right there in the courtroom after the decision: "Haha, in your face! I did murder your wife, but the trial is over so you can't do anything anymore!"
3. Same as 2, but it happens weeks or months after the trial, the suspect boasts in front of witnesses how he did it and got away with it. (and to not make it *only* hearsay, let's assume that the boasting contained actual information which could have been used as a strong evidence)

Would the suspect be protected by double jeopardy? If not, what would be the procedure of doing a retrial or a new trial?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In the US, a person is generally protected from being tried for the same offense twice, but they are not necessarily absolutely "protected". If a jury convicts a person but the judge enters a directed verdict of not guilty, the prosecution can appeal that action ([Wilson v. US](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/420/332/), 420 U.S. 332\). The reason is that the acquittal could be disposed of on appeal without subjecting the person to a second trial. In contrast, in [Fong Foo v. US](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/369/141/), 369 U.S. 141 the trial judge ordered the jury to enter a verdict of acquittal. The appeals court rejected the judges basis for ordering an acquittal: but Fong Foo was "protected" because there could not be a second trial (double jeopardy), and it does not follow that the jury would have convicted but for the judge's order.

The question reduces to the limited circumstances under which the prosecution can appeal a verdict. For instance, the prosecution can appeal a tre\-trial motion to dismiss, and since there was no trial, there is no second jeopardy. Within a single jurisdiction, the only circumstance allowing a second trial involves bribery of a judge (Aleman v. [Judges of the Circuit Court of Cook County](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/138/302/473725/), 138 F.3d 302\), where the basis for allowing a second trial is that defendant was not in jeopardy with the first trial.

New evidence does not override a defendant's protection against a second trial, whether it is new DNA evidence or a confession. It does not matter if this evidence arises seconds after the final verdict is entered, or months after. Or even before, but the prosecution was unaware.

13.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the United States, under what circumstances can a defendant be retried for the same offense after being acquitted, without violating double jeopardy protections?

A) If new DNA evidence is discovered that proves the defendant's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt
B) If the defendant confesses to the crime immediately after the verdict is announced in court
C) If it is discovered that the judge was bribed by the defendant to influence the verdict
D) If the prosecution appeals a pre-trial motion to dismiss that was granted by the judge

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A) is incorrect because new evidence, even DNA evidence, does not override double jeopardy protections once a verdict has been reached.

B) is incorrect because a confession after acquittal, even immediately after in the courtroom, does not allow for a retrial due to double jeopardy protections.

C) is correct. In the case of Aleman v. Judges of the Circuit Court of Cook County, it was established that bribery of a judge can allow for a retrial without violating double jeopardy, as the defendant was not considered to be in true jeopardy during the first trial.

D) is incorrect in this context. While the prosecution can appeal a pre-trial motion to dismiss, this doesn't involve a retrial after acquittal, as no trial has taken place yet when a pre-trial motion is granted.

documentation.title: Was Derek Chauvin protected by Castle Rock v. Gonzales, 545 U.S. 748 (2005)?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: (1\)

Was Derek Chauvin protected by Castle Rock v. Gonzales, 545 U.S. 748 (2005\)1?

(2\)

If Chauvin had not touched Floyd at all, would Chauvin be protected by Castle Rock v. Gonzales?

Meaning no attempt at arrest, no confrontation, nothing. Just let Floyd leave with his cigarettes.

(3\)

Given the apparent huge disparity in the risk\-reward calculation of a police officer taking action versus just sitting in the car, why don't all police just sit in their car all day?

---

1a court decision that says that a person cannot sue the police (in the US) for failing to enforce a law, and that the police have no duty to enforce any particular law in any particular case.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Was Derek Chauvin protected by Castle Rock v. Gonzales, 545 U.S. 748
> (2005\)?

No. [Derek Chauvin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_Chauvin), the police officer whose affirmative physical acts caused the death of George Floyd is not protected by this precedent.

*Castle Rock v. Gonzales* holds that the police do not have a duty to enforce the law that may be enforced by a private party in a civil action. Police instead have broad discretion regarding whether they will or will not take action to enforce a law.

But, when a police officer does take action affirmatively, this case does not apply. Instead, the question then, is whether the affirmative use of force by the officer was justified by the applicable substantive criminal law.

> If Chauvin had not touched Floyd at all, would Chauvin be protected by
> *Castle Rock v. Gonzales*?
> 
> 
> Meaning no attempt at arrest, no confrontation, nothing. Just let
> Floyd leave with his cigarettes.

Yes. (A much more complicated analysis applied if a fellow officer did what he did and he stood back and did nothing, but that is beyond the scope of this question as I understand it and would call for a separate question.)

> Given the apparent huge disparity in the risk\-reward calculation of a
> police officer taking action versus just sitting in the car, why don't
> all police just sit in their car all day?

Police officers who do that are routinely fired and given bad recommendation by their superiors when applying for a new law enforcement position. Law enforcement supervisors routinely punish police officers for inaction construing that as being a "coward" but are much less likely to punish a police officer for being unlawfully overzealous without strong pressure from civilians in the relevant government agency or local government.

Empirically, sitting in their car all day is not how police act. They are much more likely to be overzealous than to be docile.

This said, there is [some statistical evidence](https://www.vox.com/22360290/black-lives-matter-protest-crime-ferguson-effects-murder) that has been construed to show that following the announcement of the Chauvin prosecution and related protests before and after that was done, that police took a less active role in policing that led to higher crime.

14.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Based on the Castle Rock v. Gonzales case and its implications for police behavior, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) Police officers are legally obligated to enforce every law in every situation they encounter.

B) Derek Chauvin's actions in the George Floyd case were protected by the Castle Rock v. Gonzales precedent.

C) Police officers have broad discretion in enforcing laws, but can be held accountable for affirmative actions that violate rights or laws.

D) Police officers face equal risks whether they take action or remain passive in potential crime situations.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The Castle Rock v. Gonzales case established that police have broad discretion in enforcing laws and cannot be sued for failing to enforce a particular law. However, this protection does not extend to affirmative actions taken by officers that violate rights or laws, as seen in the Derek Chauvin case. While police have discretion, they can still be held accountable for their actions when they choose to intervene. Option A is incorrect because police are not obligated to enforce every law. Option B is wrong because Chauvin's actions were not protected by this precedent. Option D is inaccurate because there is a disparity in risk between action and inaction, with overzealousness often being less punished than perceived cowardice.

documentation.title: Can someone consent on behalf of someone else for a call-in radio show?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: There's a morning radio show that airs here (and I'm sure there are plenty others that do something similar) that does something like this:

* Girlfriend/wife suspects boyfriend/husband is cheating
* While girlfriend is secretly listening, the radio show hosts call boyfriend pretending to offer a free romantic gift
* Boyfriend says to send gift to someone other than his girlfriend
* Girlfriend catches boyfriend, lots of on\-air drama, etc

What I don't get is right before they call the boyfriend to trap him they ask the girlfriend something like "do we have your consent to put your boyfriend on the radio?"

Why is that? If this is about recording a phone call then wouldn't they already have permission to record everything once she consents (at least in one party consent states)? If something more is needed, what legal right does she have to consent on his behalf?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Don't believe everything you hear on the radio or see on TV. That radio show is probably staged with actors; read [https://didyouknowfacts.com/former\-dj\-radio\-business\-fake/](https://didyouknowfacts.com/former-dj-radio-business-fake/) and the linked AMA on Reddit.

If it happens that radio show is not entirely acted out, I'm sure the radio station has their legal ducks in a row. The station as a business and the DJ as an individual would have some legal exposure to "out" or reveal affairs on the air, so if the show is not a total act, all callers will have signed or agreed to verbal releases which state that all participants are recorded and the outcomes may be unpredictable, the station and the DJ are not liable, etc. One or two party consent for recording and broadcasting will be respected; if they weren't, the station would be sued out of existence.

The idea that they ask for consent on the air and act like that is required is simply more of the act. 99% of the listeners have no legal training, and the magic word "consent" makes the show sound more real and lawful. As above, there *could* be releases agreed to on the phone before the call is switch to broadcast, i.e. *"do you agree to let us broadcast you and are you aware of this and any ramifications?"* and that would be recorded by the station for their legal protection. But a good lawyer could get around that in court.

See also **[Is it legal for police to travel with a film crew and publicize arrest footage without consent?](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/7458/is-it-legal-for-police-to-travel-with-a-film-crew-and-publicize-arrest-footage-w)** and also **[Is 'You the Jury' TV show really legal?](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/18231/is-you-the-jury-tv-show-really-legal/18249#18249)**

15.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A popular radio show segment involves calling unsuspecting individuals to expose potential infidelity. The hosts ask for consent from the suspicious partner before making the call. Which of the following best explains the legal implications of this practice?

A) The consent request is legally necessary and sufficient to protect the radio station from liability.

B) The consent request is part of the show's dramatic presentation and has no real legal significance.

C) The consent given by one partner is legally binding for both parties involved.

D) The radio show is likely staged, and if not, would require more comprehensive legal protections beyond on-air consent.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. The documentation suggests that such radio shows are often staged with actors. If the show is genuine, it would require more comprehensive legal protections than just asking for consent on air. The station would need to have participants sign releases or agree to verbal releases off-air, covering recording, broadcasting, and liability issues. The on-air consent request is likely part of the show's dramatization rather than a legally sufficient protection. Options A and C are incorrect because they overstate the legal significance of the on-air consent request. Option B, while partially true about the dramatic aspect, doesn't address the broader legal considerations that would be necessary if the show were real.

documentation.title: Under which law is the police allowed to hold one's passport and phone after being in detention for 21 hrs?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Is the UK police allowed to hold one's passport and phone for further "investigation" after he had been in detention for 21 hours?

Further the police told him that he is not allowed to leave his flat.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [england\-and\-wales](/questions/tagged/england-and-wales "show questions tagged 'england-and-wales'")

The length of time a suspect is held in police custody before being released is unrelated to the police's power (and duty) to sieze potential evidence for further examination or to require e.g. the surrender of a passport as a condition of pre\-charge bail (along with the requirement not to apply for international travel documents or tickets etc).

If the suspect is assessed to be a flight risk, under [section 50A(2\)(a)](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1984/60/section/50A) Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (PACE) they can retain a passport if they see...

> the need to secure that the person surrenders to custody

The retention of property, such as a phone, is allowed under [section 22](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1984/60/section/22?timeline=false) PACE:

> (1\) Subject to subsection (4\) below, anything which has been seized by a constable or taken away by a constable following a requirement made by virtue of section 19 or 20 above may be retained so long as is necessary in all the circumstances.
> 
> 
> (2\) Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1\) above—
> 
> 
> * (a) anything seized for the purposes of a criminal investigation may be retained, except as provided by subsection (4\) below—
> 
> 
> 
> > * (i) for use as evidence at a trial for an offence; or
> > * (ii) **for forensic examination or for investigation in connection with an offence**; and
> 
> 
> * (b) anything may be retained in order to establish its lawful owner, where there are reasonable grounds for believing that it has been obtained in consequence of the commission of an offence.
> 
> 
> (3\) \[...]
> 
> 
> (4\) Nothing may be retained for either of the purposes mentioned in subsection (2\)(a) above if a photograph or copy would be sufficient for that purpose.
> 
> 
> \[...]

16.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A suspect has been detained by UK police for 21 hours and then released. The police have retained the suspect's passport and mobile phone for further investigation. They have also instructed the suspect not to leave their flat. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the police's actions?

A) The police have exceeded their authority by retaining the suspect's belongings after the 21-hour detention period.

B) The police can retain the passport but not the mobile phone, as electronic devices require a separate warrant for seizure.

C) The police can legally retain both the passport and the mobile phone, but cannot restrict the suspect's movements after release.

D) The police can legally retain both items and restrict the suspect's movements, provided it's part of pre-charge bail conditions.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: According to the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (PACE), the police have the authority to retain a suspect's passport under section 50A(2)(a) if they believe there is a flight risk. They can also retain other property, such as a mobile phone, under section 22 of PACE for forensic examination or investigation purposes. Additionally, the police can impose conditions as part of pre-charge bail, which may include restrictions on movement, such as not leaving one's residence. Therefore, option D is correct as it accurately reflects the police's legal powers in this situation.

documentation.title: Is it fair use to discuss a fictional work on a webpage?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: On my for\-profit website, users can rate and comment on works of literature, film, and music, most of which are copyrighted. The only information I include is:

1\.) Title

2\.) Release date

3\.) MPAA rating, if it is a movie

4\.) Similar works

Does this count as fair use of the work?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Titles can't be copyrighted](https://www.plagiarismtoday.com/2010/01/08/5-things-that-cant-be-copyrighted/).

Meta\-data like \#2 aren't copyrighted.

Not sure if the MPAA *could* protect its ratings, but I can't find anywhere that it has asserted restrictions on the use of those.

If the list of "Similar works" is not somebody else's intellectual property then there's no problem. (If it is I'm not certain what protection it could be eligible for.)

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A website owner is creating a movie database and wants to include the following information for each film: title, release date, MPAA rating, and a list of similar movies. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding potential copyright issues?

A) The website owner needs to obtain permission from copyright holders for all information listed.
B) Only the MPAA rating requires permission, as it's a trademarked system.
C) The website can freely use all this information without copyright concerns.
D) The website owner should be cautious about the source of the "similar movies" list, but the other information is generally safe to use.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because most of the information listed is not protected by copyright.
B is incorrect because MPAA ratings are generally considered factual information and can be used freely.
C is partially correct but overlooks potential issues with the "similar movies" list.
D is correct because:
1. Titles cannot be copyrighted.
2. Release dates are factual information and not subject to copyright.
3. MPAA ratings are generally considered fair use and not restricted.
4. The "similar movies" list could potentially be someone else's intellectual property if copied from another source, so caution is needed here.

This question tests understanding of copyright law as it applies to different types of information commonly used in media databases.

documentation.title: Does a company have to disclose a data breach as part of the agreement with the SEC to be publicly traded?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If I run a publicly traded company that's releasing hardware and that hardware is compromised and customer data is harvested, do I have to publicize that leak's existence? What if the people that found that data are presumed to be trustworthy and are willing to destroy the data upon payment? Does that material breach have to be announced?

Note, this is about the Ubiquiti breach which is described as "catastrophic". If they had paid the researches/hackers, and were told that the customer data was destroyed, would that breach have to announced to share holders? Can these matters legally be handled privately?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **Applicable Law**

There are (at least) two levels of regulation involved.

[At the state level](https://www.ncsl.org/research/telecommunications-and-information-technology/security-breach-notification-laws.aspx), all fifty states and all or almost all U.S. districts and territories have enacted laws requiring notifications of data breaches.

Under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, publicly held companies also have to make regular reports to the public via the Securities and Exchange Commission, some of which are on a fixed schedule and some of which are episodic for extraordinary events. The requirement under that '34 Act is to disclose all material information about the company that a reasonable investor would be influenced by in making an investment decision. There are regulations and there is case law governing what does and does not have to be disclosed, but there is still a great deal of discretion in deciding what to include.

But if your company fails to disclose information under the '34 Act and an investor sues the company for failing to disclose it, and a judge and jury handling the case determine in the court process that the information had to be disclosed under this vague standard and that someone was harmed economically as a result of the non\-disclosure, then the company (and often people affiliated with the company) have liability to the people who the court finds were harmed by the non\-disclosure for securities fraud and that liability cannot be discharged in bankruptcy in most cases (and is also eligible for special treatment in the debt collection process to enforce the judgment).

**Application**

> If I run a publicly traded company that's releasing hardware and that
> hardware is compromised and customer data is harvested, do I have to
> publicize that leak's existence?

You do if it is of a magnitude covered by state law, or if the existence of the leak would be material to an investor in the company's securities (either stock or bonds).

> What if the people that found that data are presumed to be trustworthy
> and are willing to destroy the data upon payment?

This depends on the language of an individual state disclosure law at the state level. At the federal level, the question is whether the event is material. A variety of factors could influence that conclusion. One is the amount of the payment. Another is the extent that it indicates a problem that is likely to recur, or reflects deeper management problems in the company's IT systems.

> Does that material breach have to be announced?

If the breach is material, it has to be announced. The timing of the required '34 Act disclosures is a rather arcane matter best left to specialists.

> Note, this is about the Ubiquiti breach which is described as
> "catastrophic". If they had paid the researches/hackers, and were told
> that the customer data was destroyed, would that breach have to
> announced to share holders? Can these matters legally be handled privately?

See above.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A publicly traded company experiences a significant data breach affecting customer information. The company pays the hackers to destroy the data and receives assurances that it has been done. Under which circumstances would the company be required to disclose this incident?

A) Only if required by state data breach notification laws
B) Only if the payment amount is material to the company's finances
C) Only if there's evidence the data wasn't actually destroyed
D) If it's material information that could influence a reasonable investor's decision

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The question tests understanding of disclosure requirements for publicly traded companies. While state laws (A) do require breach notifications in many cases, this isn't the only consideration for public companies. The payment amount (B) could be a factor, but materiality isn't solely based on financial impact. Proof of data destruction (C) isn't the determining factor for disclosure.

The correct answer is D because under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, publicly held companies must disclose all material information that a reasonable investor would consider important in making an investment decision. A significant data breach, even if supposedly resolved, could be considered material due to its potential impact on the company's reputation, customer trust, and future security risks. The materiality standard is broader than just financial impact and considers overall significance to the company's operations and risks.

documentation.title: Provisions on lease contract not fulfilled
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I just wanted to get a second opinion on a part of my lease since I'd rather it not come back to bite me.

Basically, I moved in May (set next renew date to September this year). When I looked at the place, it had a back room that was filled with the owners stuff (sort of a hoarder, but it wasn't just trash. Just furniture, tools, etc).
