documentation.title: Confessing for a crime which has not been committed
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: A person confessed to a lawyer over phone for a blackmailing (his lover)crime which he didn't commit. Will he able to file a complaint against that person only with his confession? But such crime has not occured and the lawyer doesn't know any other details

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The person who is blackmailed can file a criminal complaint. A random person who thinks there was a crime cannot. A person's lawyer especially cannot even anonymously tip off the police about bad past act of the client.

56.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A lawyer receives a phone call from a client who confesses to blackmailing their lover, but the lawyer later discovers that no such crime actually occurred. Which of the following actions would be most appropriate and ethical for the lawyer to take?

A) File an anonymous tip with the police about the client's confession
B) Contact the supposed victim to verify if the blackmail occurred
C) Maintain client confidentiality and take no further action
D) File a complaint against the client for making a false confession

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) Incorrect. Lawyers are bound by attorney-client privilege and cannot disclose information shared by their clients, even anonymously. This would be a breach of confidentiality.

B) Incorrect. Contacting the supposed victim would violate client confidentiality and potentially create legal complications. The lawyer should not investigate the matter independently.

C) Correct. The lawyer must maintain client confidentiality, especially since no actual crime has occurred. Even if the confession was false, the communication is still protected by attorney-client privilege.

D) Incorrect. Lawyers cannot file complaints against their own clients based on information shared in confidence. This would be a severe breach of ethics and professional conduct.

The correct action is to maintain confidentiality. Lawyers are ethically bound to protect client communications, even if they later learn the information was false or misleading. Unless there's an immediate threat of future harm, the lawyer should not take any action based on this confession.

documentation.title: What happens after a border conviction?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: This recent [Article Here](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/06/21/trumps-zero-tolerance-border-prosecutions-led-time-served-and-10-fee/722237002/) raises the question of what happens after a US border conviction. 

> On Monday, (6\-18\-18\) agents brought a Honduran man, Mariano Torres\-Perdomo, into court to face a misdemeanor charge of entering the country illegally. Border agents had caught him two days earlier crossing into Texas with his 6\-year\-old son. He quickly pleaded guilty...(he) was sentenced to time served and a $10 fee.

Presumably, he was turned over for deportation processing. So, after pleading guilty, would Torres\-Perdomo have further judicial or administrative hearings before being physically removed to his home country?

The reason I wonder, is because the BCP and DHS seem to be suggesting that detentions prior to removal may take weeks or months. 

The article actually raises a lot of other questions, but I'd like to focus on this first.

I'm not sure that this should be in Law SE or Politics SE, as it might have a home in either or both\- feel free to migrate to Politics

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> So, after pleading guilty, would Torres\-Perdomo have further judicial
>  or administrative hearings before being physically removed to his home
>  country?

No. All that would have to be done is for DHS to arrange transportation to his home country from the USA. The guilty plea would consent to deportation without further hearing.

> The reason I wonder, is because the BCP and DHS seem to be suggesting
>  that detentions prior to removal may take weeks or months.

I think that this is in cases where there is not a guilty plea, for example, where an asylum claim is made by the person detained.

documentation.title: Is reading obscene written material online illegal in the UK?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am quite confused by what seems at the outset to be a very simple question in the UK's obscenity laws. Suppose a person puts an obscene story on a website (we'll call them the Writer) and another person reads the story (we'll call them the Reader). 

Is the Reader guilty of 'publishing' the material and therefore in breach of the 1959 Obscene Publications Act?

In the normal sense, 'publication' is defined in an online context as 

"*to submit (content) online*, as to a message board or blog: I published a comment on her blog post with examples from my own life." 
according to www.dictionary.com (emphasis added is mine). 

In the context of the Obscene Publications Act, the word 'publishes' seems to have been redefined, appropriated to become a piece of legalese that no longer reflects the original meaning of the word. The wording of the Act states (emphasis mine) \-

(3\)For the purposes of this Act a person publishes an article who—

(a)distributes, circulates, sells, lets on hire, gives, or lends it, or who offers it for sale or for letting on hire; or

(b)in the case of an article containing or embodying matter to be looked at or a record, shows, plays or projects it \[F1, **or, where the matter is data stored electronically, transmits that data**.]:

. . . F2

What does it mean to 'transmit' that data? Regina vs Waddon has shown that transmission is said to have occurred when the data is uploaded to the Website by the Author or downloaded from the Website by the Reader. In both those instances, the Author was deemed to have 'published' the article. (The reason it mattered was that although the Website was hosted abroad, the UK\-resident Author had still broken the UK law when the material was downloaded in the UK so he could therefore be prosecuted). 

But what about the Reader? ... This nebulous wording seems to imply all manner of things.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The answer to your question is 'No'. The 1959 Act only creates an offence relating to the sale, production, promotion or publication of material that is obscene for the purposes of the Act.

The crucial issue is the nature of the "obscene material". Under the 1959 Act, the test is in s1(1\) "deprave and corrupt". 

There are examples of where it is an offence to be in possession of certain materials: child pornography or material that could be used in the preparation of a terrorist act are obvious examples.

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Under the UK's Obscene Publications Act of 1959, which of the following actions would most likely be considered "publishing" obscene material?

A) A person reading an obscene story on a website
B) A person uploading an obscene story to a website hosted in another country
C) A person sharing a link to an obscene story on social media
D) A person saving an obscene story to their personal computer

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A) is incorrect because merely reading obscene material is not considered publishing under the Act. The reader is not distributing or transmitting the data.

B) is correct because uploading content to a website, even if hosted abroad, is considered "transmitting data" and thus falls under the Act's definition of publishing. This is supported by the Regina vs Waddon case mentioned in the passage.

C) is a gray area not specifically addressed in the given information, but sharing a link is less likely to be considered publishing than directly uploading content.

D) is incorrect because saving a story to a personal computer does not involve distribution or transmission to others, which are key elements of "publishing" under the Act.

The correct answer aligns with the Act's definition of publishing, which includes "transmits that data" in the case of electronically stored material, and is further supported by the legal precedent mentioned in the passage.

documentation.title: Guarantor liability and e-signatures (UK)
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am based in the UK and have a tenant in a property that is not paying their rent. The tenancy agreement was signed in Oct 2020 and there are rent arrears for the last few months.

I have a guarantor agreement signed with the tenant's dad acting as the guarantor where he is liable to pay any unpaid rent.

The tenancy agreement and the guarantor agreement were both signed using a popular online esignature platform, which as far as I have researched, is a perfectly legal and acceptable way to sign a contract.

The guarantor has confirmed the email address to which the guarantor agreement was emailed is his own, personal account.

However, the guarantor is claiming the tenant (his son) has access to his email address and signed the guarantor agreement fraudulently \- presumably without his knowledge.

It might be useful to know the guarantor has claimed the son has also fraudulently set up other forms of credit (e.g. payday loans) this way and the guarantor has allegedly filed a report with the police. It is unclear if the tenant still has access to the guarantor's email account.

In this scenario, is the guarantor still liable to pay the unpaid rent arrears? If he successfully claims the documents were signed fraudulently, can he still be liable by means or being complicit or aware of his son's activity, not least by (presumably) seeing the emails coming through after signature over the last 10 months?

Any comments are appreciated

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If the purported guarantor can prove the facts stated then they are not a guarantor
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You can rely on the signature and the onus of proving it isn’t theirs on the balance of probabilities rests on the guarantor. However, if they can do that, then they never agreed to be guarantor and you’re out of luck.

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In a UK tenancy dispute, a landlord claims the tenant's father signed a guarantor agreement using an e-signature platform. The father alleges his son fraudulently signed the agreement using his email account. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal implications?

A) The guarantor is automatically liable for the unpaid rent, regardless of the fraud claim.

B) The landlord must prove the guarantor personally signed the agreement to enforce it.

C) If the guarantor can prove fraud on the balance of probabilities, he is not liable as a guarantor.

D) The guarantor is liable due to negligence in allowing his son access to his email account.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the documentation, if the purported guarantor can prove the facts stated (in this case, that his son fraudulently signed the agreement) on the balance of probabilities, then they are not considered a guarantor. The onus of proving the signature isn't theirs rests on the guarantor, but if they can successfully do so, they never agreed to be a guarantor and are not liable for the unpaid rent. Options A and D incorrectly assume liability regardless of fraud, while B incorrectly places the burden of proof on the landlord.
